Award.AwardTitle: Rigid-Analytic Geometry and Representation Theory of p-adic Groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project has two main aspects. Firstly, to investigate the geometry of certain rigid-analytic moduli spaces by analyzing the representations of p-adic groups furnished by the l-adic etale cohomology groups of these spaces. Secondly, we aim at understanding the representation theory of reductive p-adic groups by making use of Rigid-Analytic Geometry.

1) The first aspect concerns the moduli spaces of p-divisible groups and their covering spaces, as defined by M. Rapoport and Th. Zink.
A conjecture of R. Kottwitz predicts that the cohomology groups in question realize local Langlands correspondences. We develop and extend methods to show that the l-adic cohomology realizes correspondences of Jacquet-Langlands type, at least on the level of characters. We treat in detail some cases in which the phenomenon of endoscopy plays a significant role.

2) The second aspect is about the theory of locally analytic representations of reductive p-adic groups. Here we aim at developing a localization theory which unifies simultaneously the localization theory of A. Beilinson and J. Bernstein for Lie algebra representations, and the localization theory of P. Schneider and U. Stuhler for smooth representations. The theory of Rigid-Analytic Spaces provides a framework to relate these two theories.

The project's main theme is that of symmetries, families of symmetries (i.e., groups), about relating different kinds of symmetries, and studying symmetries in terms of the geometry of spaces (and vice versa). This is a classic approach, but is done for a class of symmetries and spaces that, so far, have not been well understood. The projects aim at unifying and better understanding theories that have been considered as separate branches so far. This is the case for the so-called smooth representation theory, and the representation theory of Lie algebras. The results will also help to understand the geometry of moduli spaces which are defined by polynomial equations with integral coefficients, e.g., integral models of Shimura varieties, and as such, are expected to deepen our knowledge about these fundamental objects in Geometry and Number Theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work on this project has been very successful as many of the envisioned goals have been accomplished, and some unforeseen, though highly welcome, results and applications have been obtained.

(1) Some background. The project falls in the general area of representation theory of groups. The origin of the mathematical notion of a group is tied to that of symmetry. For instance, a regular triangle (having all sides of equal length) has six symmetries: there are three rotational symmetries (this includes the identity map), as well as three reflections along the perpendicular bisectors. Performing two symmetries consecutively gives another symmetry, which is one reason why they form a "group". Another example is the group of symmetries of a 3-dimensional space which preserve the origin and preserve distances. By its very definition, this group acts naturally on the 3-dimensional linear space.

It has been a key insight in the history of mathematics that it is useful to study all possible ways in which a group can act on a linear space. Any such action is called a representation, and understanding all representations of a group means, roughly speaking, to understand the group.

This project is concerned with groups, the so-called p-adic groups, which play an important role in Number Theory. Here, p is a prime number. For any prime number p one can consider the field of p-adic numbers, which serves to understand number-theoretical problems with emphasis on the prime number p. The p-adic groups which are studied in this project are then subgroups of groups of invertible matrices whose entries are p-adic numbers. Those groups are equipped with an analytic structure, i.e., one can consider differentiable functions on such groups, and functions which can be expanded into convergent power series. The latter functions are called analytic.

The main focus of the project was to develop methods which serve to understand so-called locally analytic representations of p-adic groups. A representation is called locally analytic if the group action on any vector in the representation space can locally be expanded into a convergent power series (whose coefficients are vectors in the representation space).

(2) Summary of the objectives of this project. Our main plan was to establish a very general method of analyzing and constructing locally analytic representations. An important role in locally analytic representation theory is played by the Lie algebra of the group G in question, and any locally analytic representation is, in particular, a representation of the Lie algebra Lie(G). In the 1980's A. Beilinson and J. Bernstein, and, independently, J.-L. Brylinsky and M.Kashiwara, have developed a so-called Localization Theory  for representations of such Lie algebras as we consider them here (these are reductive Lie algebras). This theory associates to any representation of the Lie algebra a sheaf over the flag variety of G. This sheaf is, additionally, equipped with an action of the sheaf of differential operators, i.e., it is a so-called D-module. Moreover, one can recover the Lie algebra representation from the corresponding D-module, and this allows one to go back and forth between Lie algebra representations and D-modules.

The goal was thus to extend the localization theory of Beilinson-Bernstein and Brylinsky-Kashiwara to locally analytic representations of p-adic groups, and this has been achieved in the paper "D-affinity of formal models of flag varieties" which the author wrote together with C. Huyghe, D. Patel and T. Schmidt. Moreover, together with D. Patel and T. Schmidt he wrote a series of four papers which served as preliminary studies to the main work mentioned above. In particular, the paper "Locally analytic representations of GL(2,L) via semistable models of P^1" contains an explicit version of the whole theory for the special case of the group of invertible 2x2-matrices. A major application of this theory, given in the latter paper, was a proof of the admissibility  (in the sense of P. Schneider and J. Teitelbaum) of certain representations which are geometrically constructed via a covering space of the p-adic upper half plane. There is, as of now, no other method available to proof this result, except if the fiel L (the coefficient field of the group GL(2,L)) is a general finite extension of the field of p-adic numbers. (If L is equal to the field of p-adic numbers, then, by completely different methods, the admissibility of these representations has been shown by G. Dospinescu and A.-C. Le Bras.)

(3) Conclusion. The work accomplished in this project opens the gate  to better understand representations of groups which play an important role in Number Theory. Its usefulness has been demonstrated by being successfully applied to certain problems. It has raised a number of questions and has already stimulated future work in this field, e.g., the problem of classifying locally analytic representations.
